quoteFirst: Combe was ordered to withdraw to Beaufort, but considering it impossible to do this in daylight and in close contact with the enemy, he decided to hold on till it was sufficiently dark to give his troops a chance of getting back in safety. At 3 P.M. the enemy again attacked and reached the centre of the village, but the few men of the garrison who remained held on to the west edge until
quoteLast: , when the enemy closed in on both flanks. Then the only survivors--two officers and nine men--withdrew, still firing with good effect on the Germans as they over-ran the position.
title: The history of the Twentieth (Light) Division
author: Inglefield, Valentine Erskine, 1886-1947; Cavan, Frederick Rudolph Lambart, Earl of, 1865-1946 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteLast: --Came to at Ascension. Found here _Mæander_, _Tortoise_, and _Buffalo_.
title: A sailor's life under four sovereigns, Volume 3 (of 3)
author: Keppel, Henry, Sir, 1809-1904

quoteFirst: Garrett had called up to say that the feed before the game would begin at seven bells; so I and the Missus figured on bein' on hand at half past six, so as to get acquainted with some of our fellow club members and know what to call 'em when we wanted the gravy passed or somethin'. But I had trouble with my studs and it wasn't till pretty near
quoteLast: that we rung the Garretts' bell. The hired girl let us in and left us standin' in the hall w'ile she went to tell Mrs. Garrett we was there. Pretty soon the girl come back and says she would take our wraps and that Mrs.
title: Gullible's Travels, Etc.
author: Lardner, Ring, 1885-1933; Preston, May Wilson, 1873-1949 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Barbara Hare rose with a gesture of impatience, not suppressed, opened the door, and glanced at the large clock in the hall. “It wants nine and
quoteLast: , mamma. I wish you would put your watch on of a day; four times you have sent me to look at that clock since dinner.”
title: East Lynne
author: Wood, Henry, Mrs., 1814-1887

quoteLast: ," I said, "and I never care to run a train to the last moment. There is no help for it, I suppose I must go without seeing Murdock. Cressley will in all probability send down a message to-morrow for the papers he requires."
title: A Master of Mysteries
author: Meade, L. T., 1854-1914; Eustace, Robert, 1869-1943; Walton, J. Ambrose, 1874- [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: During the afternoon it seemed to have difficulty in holding the line it had gained, and the 61st Brigade and the guns in support of it assisted by bringing artillery and machine-gun fire to bear on parts of the enemy line near Bas Maisnil. About half-past four a counter attack drove back the 8th Division troops, who were reported at
quoteLast: to be again holding their original line.
title: The history of the Twentieth (Light) Division
author: Inglefield, Valentine Erskine, 1886-1947; Cavan, Frederick Rudolph Lambart, Earl of, 1865-1946 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteLast: when the lawyer finally finished, locked certain papers away in the safe, and went to his room, to change. By seven he was welcoming Wilfred Barlow in the hall, where the young doctor stood talking to Jill.
title: The sting
author: Le Queux, William, 1864-1927

quoteFirst: Some engineers, to change the simile, would have argued that the engine was off the track, and that therefore the train was not in running condition; but Orville merely changed engines. His own steam having been cut off, he ordered an automobile for
quoteLast: ; and after he had bathed and bandaged his ankle he determined, with a grit worthy of the cause that brought it forth, to attend that dinner even if he paid for it in the hospital, with Annette as special nurse.
title: Araminta and the Automobile
author: Loomis, Charles Battell, 1861-1911; Lang, Otto [Illustrator]
